subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-Up and QS-Nu: 2 proposals for a new QS keyboard mapping (revision 2)
msgSnippet: ... Is there any particular reason you prefer to map #15 to upper-case _c_ and alt-#36 to lower-case _c_? I find spellings like {bYsikcl} a good deal more
messageBody:
On 20.12.2007 Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> This is a revision of the QS-Nu proposal. The only changes from the
> previous version are:
>
> QS Number QS-Nu
> 21 G
> alt-23 N
> 15 C
> alt-36 c
> 10 V
> 39 v
>
>

Is there any particular reason you prefer to map
#15 to upper-case _c_ and alt-#36 to lower-case _c_?

I find spellings like {bYsikcl} a good deal more
dyslectic than {bYsikCl}. It seems to me that capitalization
has a
signal value that a letter is not what you'd
expect it to be in terms of TO.

Those hunches about what looks more or less weird are
of course deeply personal. I choose to use B for #38/#37
because {bBt} and {ubBt} looked less weird to me than
{mMst} and {mMT}, and likewise {Myr}/{Mur} more like
_were_ than {Byr}/{Bur} -- which is of course only
because the shape of {B} recalls the (Greek) _ou_
ligature, and {M} the shape of _W_ to me.

I've been thinking of producing a number of parallel
example text in the different proposals, so that they
can be compared in running text. However some of
the entries in Ted's reference file are garbled:
the Jerome non-ASCII characters come out wrong,
and the non-ASCII characters in the other columns
come out as question marks? Is it the software at
my end which is playing tricks?

{beGkt fIlip yVnsVn}
{Y bet yu kVdnt ges Dat prununsiESun! :-)}

> 
> QS Number QS-Nu
> 21 G
> alt-23    N
> 15    C
> alt-36    c
> 10    V
> 39    v
>

Is there any particular reason you prefer to map
#15 to upper-case _c_ and alt-#36 to lower-case _c_?

I find spellings like {bYsikcl} a good deal more
dyslectic than {bYsikCl}. It seems to me that capitalization 
has a
signal value that a letter is not what you'd
expect it to be in terms of TO.

Those hunches about what looks more or less weird are
of course deeply personal.  I choose to use B for #38/#37
because {bBt} and {ubBt} looked less weird to me than
{mMst} and {mMT}, and likewise {Myr}/{Mur} more like
_were_ than {Byr}/{Bur} -- which is of course only
because the shape of {B} recalls the (Greek) _ou_
ligature, and {M} the shape of _W_ to me.

I've been thinking of producing a number of parallel
example text in the different proposals, so that they
can be compared in running text.  However some of
the entries in Ted's reference file are garbled:
the Jerome non-ASCII characters come out wrong,
and the non-ASCII characters in the other columns
come out as question marks?  Is it the software at
my end which is playing tricks?
